content.webTitle: ‘Syria-bound’ British family detained in Moldova after being held in Turkey

fields.headline: ‘Syria-bound’ British family detained in Moldova after being held in Turkey
fields.bodyText: A British family held in Turkey on suspicion of seeking to travel to a part of Syria under the control of Islamic State have now been detained in Moldova, the UK Foreign Office has said. Asif Malik, 31, his partner, Sara Kiran, 29, and their four children – all aged under eight – were arrested in Ankara last month after British police launched an appeal to track their whereabouts. A Foreign Office spokesman said: “We can confirm the detention of a British family in Moldova. We are working closely with UK and Moldavian authorities to help ensure their wellbeing. We will not comment further on cases involving minors.” An unnamed Turkish official had previously said that the family would be deported to Moldova “of their own will”. The Foreign Office said the family had sought consular assistance during their detainment in Turkey, but was unable to give any further details. “Whether we’re involved in the case in the future depends on the family. If they approach us as British nationals in distress then we will be available to provide consular assistance if they require that.” Police launched an appeal to trace the Malik family last month, after it was discovered they had left their home in Slough, Berkshire, without informing their family and friends or mentioning any holiday or travel plans. Officers established that the couple, their daughter, Zoha, seven, and sons Essa, four, Zakariya, two and one-year-old Yhaha boarded a ferry from Dover to Calais on 8 April. The family were reported missing on 16 April and Kiran’s relatives made an emotional appeal for her to get in touch, saying: “We miss you.” Turkish officials said the family crossed into Turkey by land from Greece via the town of Kirklareli on 16 April and were detained on 20 April after a tipoff from British police. John Campbell, the acting deputy chief constable of Thames Valley police, said: “Given the online rhetoric from the Islamic State encouraging people to travel to Syria, the direction of travel and concerns voiced by Asif’s family, Thames Valley police is concerned the family may be seeking to travel to Syria.” Campbell said police were not drawing any conclusions about the family’s intentions. “I’m not suggesting for one moment that they are intending to join Islamic State. I don’t think there’s anything to suggest that,” he said. “We know that having gone into Europe, their general direction of travel is towards Turkey, thereby we make the assumption towards Syria. At the same time, we know that the [wider] family have voiced some concerns about the family’s intentions. There’s been a suggestion that Mr Asif in the past has said that he would like to live in a Muslim state.” Anjem Choudary, the former leader of the banned radical group al-Muhajiroun, described Malik as a “champion for sharia” (Islamic law) who regularly attended al-Muhajiroun events and demonstrations. In a statement issued through police, Malik’s family said: “With the reality that our loved one, Asif Malik, and his family have left the UK without any notice, our lives have been completely devastated. “We are totally distraught, upset and in shock. The greatest sadness is the decision by Asif and Sara to travel with their young family, such beautiful children. “Please, Asif, we ask you to think about what has happened and the decisions you have made. Please can you ring us or send us a message to let us know that you and the children are well. All we wish for is your safe return and especially the return of the children. We are not angry with you, we are just heartbroken. “We ask that if there are others out there considering leaving the UK in this manner, please consider the impact on the family members that you leave behind.”
